Award.AwardTitle: Visualizing Molecular Dynamics in Large Molecules using Intense, femtosecond, Pump-Probe Laser Pulses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program will make "molecular movies" that will be used to study fundamental physical and chemical processes induced in molecules by laser light. The goal of this investigation is to determine the time it takes for light-induced transformations to occur in large molecules. This is important because light-induced processes occur continuously in our environment, for example from sunlight shining on earth's atmosphere, plant leaves, and human skin. This team will record "molecular movies" by using strong table-top laser pulses. One pulse will be used to initiate the ionization of the molecular valence electrons orbitals, and then a second pulse and an ion detection system will be used to capture the time-evolution of the transformation. The molecules that will be studied, including ethanol and endohedral fullerenes, are relevant for industries and can serve as test-pieces for the measurement protocols developed by this team. The molecular movies that this project will produce are important because they will reveal physical and chemical processes that drive specific reactions with these molecules. Students and postdocs that get trained on this project learn skills that they will use for future jobs in academia and industry.

This research program will focus on investigating the time-resolved photo-induced isomerization of alcohol and the time evolution of endohedral fullerenes (M3N@C80) in the long-wavelength (IR) multiphoton ionization and the tunneling regimes. The goal for the latter experiment is to understand the role of excited super atomic molecular orbital (SAMO) states in these two different energy regimes. The experiments will be carried out using table-top laser pump-probe technique and the resulting charged fragments will be detected using an electron-ion-ion coincidence monitor known as a Cold-Target Recoil Ion Momentum Spectroscopy (COLTRIMS) system. The underlying dynamics will thus be revealed by coincident ion-momentum imaging. This team's contribution to advance science stems from their advanced approach to probe, in real time, and at the femtosecond scale, physical and chemical processes. This is achieved by using intense femtosecond table-top laser with twin optical parametric amplifiers which will enable 2-color pump-probe experiments and will push the current limit of fundamental femtosecond time-resolved large molecular dynamics investigations. This work will be done in partnership with theorists, which will allow this team to understand quantitatively the complexity of the physical processes and which will validate or push forward the calculations/modeling in cases of disagreements between experiment and theory.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Project Title: Visualizing Molecular Dynamics in Large Molecules using Intense, femtosecond, Pump-Probe Laser Pulses
Nora Berrah, University of Connecticut, Physics Department

 

The investigation of the interaction of molecules with short laser pulses is a very active field of research because studying photo-induced reactions that transform molecules from one structure to another is essential to physical sciences. Molecular photoabsorption, which results in the formation of excited molecules, displays a diverse range of photodecomposition reactions which we aim to understand by carryout experiments coupled with calculations. Although our understanding of molecular dynamics has progressed tremendously, much is to be investigated to understand what drives important transformations regarding the interaction of table-top lasers photons with molecules in physics. These fundamental results impact and are essential in the fields of chemistry and biology.  

 

The past three years, we investigated physical phenomena due to the conversion of laser photon energy into chemical energy via physical and chemical dynamics. We studied the interaction of the laser light with molecules that leads to structural transformation of the molecule where hydrogen atoms move from one end of the molecule to another if they absorb visible or UV light.  In some cases, two hydrogen atom break their bond and move in succession to the end of the molecule that has an oxygen atom. We used ultrafast lasers because molecular bond breaking often proceeds on very fast time scales.  Our experimental technique allowed the measurement of a molecular movie and enabled watching the making and breaking of chemical bonds. Questions we wanted to answer are: Which bond is breaking first? How are the atoms moving after the dissociation of the molecule? Why? Can we influence the outcome of the photo-induced reactions? The answer to these questions, in collaboration with theorists, enables us to contribute detail understanding to the early stage of quantum mechanical processes.  Our direct observations of multichannel photodissociation dynamics of mid-size molecules, in real-time with femtosecond pulses and imaging techniques, allowed us to uncover and elucidate intricate and previously unknown details and complexities.

 

Our objectives to contribute new knowledge to fundamental time-resolved non-adiabatic molecular dynamics at the femtosecond timescale led to publications published in the journal Nature communication and the Journal of Physical Chemical Letters.  Seven undergraduate students graduated with their bachelor with research experience that allowed them to either find immediate employment or go to graduate schools. Two master students find immediate employment in industry. One postdoc found employment in academia and industry and one PhD student was hired as a postdoctoral fellow.
